The claim cites a story from Snowriders: a website dedicated to ski and snowboarding enthusiasts, as the source of the information.
The story quotes a University spokesman: Dr. Alan Rainmaker, who expresses concern about the use of DHMO in the snow-sports industry and mentions resorts using concentrations as high as 100%.
The expert: s verdict reveals that DHMO is actually water (H2O) and that the claim is an apparent April Fool's prank that has been circulating for years. It also mentions previous instances where officials fell for the hoax, such as the case of Aliso Viejo city officials in California in 2004.
